text: In Python, I have the following example class :

code:
class Foo:
    self._attr = 0

    @property
    def attr(self):
        return self._attr

    @attr.setter
    def attr(self, value):
        self._attr = value

    @attr.deleter
    def attr(self):
        del self._attr

text: As you can see, I have a simple "private" attribute "_attr" and a property to access it.
There is a lot of codes to declare a simple private attribute and I think that it's not respecting the "KISS" philosophy to declare all attributes like that.
So, why not declare all my attributes as public attributes if I don't need a particular getter/setter/deleter ?

My answer will be :
Because the principle of encapsulation (OOP) says otherwise!
